results.title: Golden Globes Nominations 2022: The Complete List
results.abstract: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association announced a list that showed some improvement on its goal of diversifying the awards. But questions still hover over the ceremony.

multimedia.caption: Nominated for Globes were the “King Richard” performers Aunjanue Ellis, left, and Will Smith (with Mikayla Bartholomew, second from left, Saniyya Sidney, Demi Singleton and Danielle Lawson).
multimedia.copyright: Warner Brothers Pictures, via Associated Press

results.title: Spielberg’s ‘West Side Story’ Opens to Tepid Box Office Receipts
results.abstract: Musicals often take time to build an audience, but can this remake, with little star power, compete with franchises and spectacles?

multimedia.caption: Ariana DeBose, center, as Anita in “West Side Story,” which opened in theaters this weekend.

results.title: ‘West Side Story’ Review: In Love and War, 1957 Might Be Tonight
results.abstract: Steven Spielberg rediscovers the breathing, troubling essence of a classic, building a bold and current screen musical with no pretense to perfection.

multimedia.caption: Ansel Elgort and Rachel Zegler as Tony and Maria in Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story.”

results.title: Best Movies of 2021
results.abstract: Even when a film wasn’t great, filmgoing was. But there were some truly wonderful releases, ranging from music docs and musicals to westerns and the just plain weird.
results.byline: By A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)
Bad Luck Banging or Loony Porn (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Benedict Cumberbatch in “The Power of the Dog,” left, Kristen Stewart in “Spencer” and Ariana DeBose in “West Side Story.”
multimedia.copyright: From left: Kirsty Griffin/Netflix; Pablo Larrain/Neon; Niko Tavernise/20th Century Studios

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a prude mutant, a vengeful witch, a tortured musician and a demonic dinner.

multimedia.caption: Annes Elwy in “The Feast.”

results.title: Hollywood Still Matters. These Actors Showed Why.
results.abstract: Even as theaters suffer, cinema has been thriving during the pandemic — thanks to the intimacy movies create between performer and audience.
des_facet: Bad Luck Banging or Loony Porn (Movie)

results.title: ‘Red Rocket’ Review: All My XXX’s Live in Texas
results.abstract: A porn star returns to his hometown in Sean Baker’s latest slice of hard-luck Americana.

multimedia.caption: Simon Rex as Mikey and Suzanna Son as Strawberry in “Red Rocket,” directed by Sean Baker.

results.title: Five Holiday Movies to Stream
results.abstract: A list of quality holiday movies on streaming services other than Netflix.
des_facet: The Housewives of the North Pole (Movie)

multimedia.caption: From front left, Mary Steenburgen, Jane Levy and Skylar Astin in “Zoey's Extraordinary Christmas.”

results.title: The Best Actors of 2021
results.abstract: Our annual celebration of the performances that stayed with us — including Kristen Stewart, Will Smith, Ruth Negga and Benedict Cumberbatch.

multimedia.copyright: Ruven Afanador for The New York Times

results.title: Suzette Winter, Who Documented Hollywood’s Golden Age, Dies at 90
results.abstract: She and her husband produced more than 30 rosy biographical films for television about the era’s biggest stars.

multimedia.caption: Suzette Winter Feldman and her husband, Gene, right, posed with the actor Gregory Peck in an undated photo. The couple produced more than two dozen film biographies of Hollywood figures.

results.title: What Did Stephen Sondheim Really Think of ‘Rent’?
results.abstract: The composer served as something of a mentor to Jonathan Larson and spoke frankly about the show after the younger man’s death.

multimedia.caption: Jonathan Larson, left, sometimes turned to Stephen Sondheim for advice.
multimedia.copyright: From left: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Oliver Morris/Getty Images

results.title: Pedro Almodóvar Is Still Making Movies That Shock
results.abstract: He built his reputation with raunchy farces. But in his new film, “Parallel Mothers,” the 72-year-old dredges up his country’s most painful history.

multimedia.copyright: Rafael Pavarotti for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe’ Review: Success? That’s a Stretch.
results.abstract: This formulaic documentary focuses on the individuals swindled by the multilevel marketing company known for leggings, LuLaRoe.
des_facet: The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Sharon Tucker, a former LuLaRoe retailer, and her son Elijah, a former LuLaRoe employee, look at unsold leggings in “The Rise and Fall of LuLaRoe.”

results.title: How Do You Tell the World That Doomsday Has Arrived?
results.abstract: A new film about a killer comet revives memories of a nail-biting night in The Times newsroom two decades ago.

multimedia.caption: Jennifer Lawrence and Leonardo DiCaprio are astronomers trying to sound the alarm for a comet heading toward Earth in the film “Don’t Look Up.”

results.title: Denis O’Brien, Force in Ex-Beatle’s Film Company, Dies at 80
results.abstract: He and George Harrison created Handmade Films to make “Monty Python’s Life of Brian.” Other successes followed, but the partnership ended badly.

multimedia.caption: Denis O’Brien with George Harrison during the filming of the 1986 movie “Shanghai Surprise” in Surrey, England. The two were partners in the film production company Handmade Films.

results.title: Sundance Film Festival Unveils 2022 Lineup That Reflects ‘Age of Reckoning’
results.abstract: Films addressing racism and abortion are among the 82 titles that will screen when the event returns in person in January.

multimedia.caption: Keke Palmer in “Alice,” one of several festival films that explore racism and privilege through the lens of Black women.

results.title: ‘A Son (Un Fils)’ Review: The Pain of Others
results.abstract: In this Tunisian drama, a terrorist attack sends a husband and wife into a spiraling crisis, opening a world of hurt and understanding.

multimedia.caption: Fares (Sami Bouajila) and Meriem (Najla Ben Abdallah) are the parents of an 11-year-old son who is injured in “A Son.”

results.title: ‘France’ Review: When the Journalist Becomes the Story
results.abstract: Léa Seydoux plays a star television anchor whose life comes unraveled in Bruno Dumont’s new film.

multimedia.caption: Léa Seydoux’s character, France de Meurs, spirals through a series of personal and professional crises.

results.title: ‘The Lady of Heaven’ Review: A Tale of Two Eras
results.abstract: This historical epic about the life of Fatima, the daughter of the Prophet Muhammad, is a mechanical history lesson riddled with clichés.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “The Lady of Heaven.”

results.title: Lina Wertmüller, Italian Director of Provocative Films, Dies at 93
results.abstract: She established an idiosyncratic reputation for blending tragedy, farce, politics and sex. She was the first woman nominated for a best director Oscar.

multimedia.caption: Lina Wertmüller in 2019, when she received an honorary Academy Award for her filmmaking achievements.
multimedia.copyright: Mark Von Holden/Invision, via Associated Press

results.title: ‘Beijing Spring’ Review: The Politics of Aesthetics
results.abstract: This new documentary chronicles the movement for democratic artistic expression that exploded in the wake of the Cultural Revolution in China.

multimedia.caption: Archival footage, as seen in the documentary “Beijing Spring.”

results.title: ‘The Real Charlie Chaplin’ Review: Not Enough Funny Business
results.abstract: The documentary attempts to restore a sense of mystery to Chaplin’s life and work, but the filmmakers mostly run through a well-trodden timeline.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the documentary “The Real Charlie Chaplin,” directed by Peter Middleton and James Spinney.

results.title: ‘National Champions’ Review: A College Football Revolution
results.abstract: Athletes go on strike seeking health insurance in this drama as a coach tries to forge his legacy.

multimedia.caption: J.K. Simmons as a coach whose players go on strike, in “National Champions,” directed by Ric Roman Waugh.

results.title: ‘Agnes’ Review: A Crisis of Faith, and Filmmaking
results.abstract: In this plodding horror-drama from Mickey Reece, a possessed nun drives one of her sisters to leave their convent.

multimedia.caption: Molly C. Quinn as Mary in “Agnes.”

results.title: ‘Joy Womack: The White Swan’ Review: When Success Is a Stretch
results.abstract: This documentary chronicles an American ballet dancer’s efforts to become a star in Russia.

multimedia.caption: The dancer Joy Womack in “Joy Womack: The White Swan.”

results.title: ‘Encounter’ Review: The Scenic Route
results.abstract: A volatile veteran attempts to rescue his sons from a perceived alien threat in this confused cross between sci-fi thriller and family drama.

multimedia.caption: From left, Lucian-River Chauhan, Riz Ahmed and Aditya Geddada in “Encounter.”

results.title: ‘Back to the Outback’ Review: Pest in Show
results.abstract: A group of reptile house critters escape from an Australian zoo in this endearing animated adventure.

multimedia.caption: From left, Doug (voiced by Keith Urban), Pretty Boy (Tim Minchin) and Doreen (Gia Carides) in “Back to the Outback.”

results.title: ‘Last and First Men’ Review: Pondering Posterity
results.abstract: Tilda Swinton narrates the bleak future of humanity in the only feature directed by the Icelandic composer Johann Johannsson.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Last and First Men.”

results.title: ‘The Unforgivable’ Review: Mirthless in Seattle
results.abstract: Sandra Bullock plays a woman on parole in this Netflix film adaptation of a British mini-series.

multimedia.caption: Sandra Bullock in “The Unforgivable.”

results.title: ‘Mr. Saturday Night’ Review: A Producer Who Found His Groove
results.abstract: If you expect to learn much about Robert Stigwood, this new documentary about the famed manager (of the Bee Gees) and producer (of “Saturday Night Fever”) will leave you frustrated.

multimedia.caption: Robert Stigwood, the subject of the documentary “Mr. Saturday Night.”

results.title: Will Smith Is Done Trying to Be Perfect
results.abstract: “Strategizing about being the biggest movie star in the world — that is all completely over. ”

multimedia.caption: Will Smith
multimedia.copyright: Ruven Afanador for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Being the Ricardos’ Review: Kiss, Fight, Rinse, Repeat
results.abstract: Nicole Kidman and Javier Bardem star as Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in Aaron Sorkin’s drama about one very bad week.

multimedia.caption: Nicole Kidman and Javier Bardem in “Being the Ricardos.”

results.title: ‘Fatal Distraction’ Review: Parents Go Through the Unthinkable
results.abstract: In the documentary by Susan Morgan Cooper, a father is on trial after his baby dies in the back seat of a hot car.

multimedia.caption: Leanna Taylor, the mother of Cooper, in “Fatal Distraction,” a documentary by Susan Morgan Cooper.

results.title: The Oscars Are Broken. Here’s How to Fix Them.
results.abstract: The ratings flop that was the last ceremony provided useful lessons in what not to do. But there are steps the academy can take for an actually enjoyable evening.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: The Oscars, like this statue, need their luster restored.
